abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the China - Yangzhou
            Thermal Power Project were as follows: the outcome was
            satisfactory, the sustainability was highly likely, the
            institutional development impact was substantial, the Bank
            performance was satisfactory, and the borrower performance
            was highly likely. The lessons learned indicated that a
            gradual, realistic approach to major structural change in
            the power sector towards greater market orientation tailored
            to country condition and incentives, can be very effective
            in creating a solid foundation from which to launch
            accelerated reforms. A clear, long-term vision for the power
            sector combined with a baseline of achievable actions and
            strategic flexibility in supervision can allow the project
            to advance sector reform when the opportunity arises.
            Resettlement involving a change in lifestyle requires a
            higher participatory effort in impact and compensation
            assessment. Initially there was an underestimation of
            compensation for populations resettled from rural areas to
            the town center. The approach of combining policy dialogue
            at the Central Government level with the testing of the
            policy through operations in selected provincial power
            companies was a key element in successful project outcome.
            Given the enormous size of the country-with several tiers of
            government and varying issues among the
            regions/provinces-the pilot testing of reform ideas on model
            projects before moving to broad applicability, has been a
            prudent and successful approach. A high sense of
            environmental awareness and ownership by implementing
            agencies and concerned authorities and detailed
            Environmental Management Plan are required to produce highly
            satisfactory environmental results. The introduction of
            international competitive bidding and multiple suppliers
            along with substantial local contracting can reduce costs
            but requires close interfacing of engineering design parameters.

5079618.majtheme: Environment and natural resource management,Financial and private sector development

repnme.cdata!:
China - Yangzhou Thermal Power Project :
            environmental assessment report

abstracts.cdata!:
This is an environmental assessment of
            the Yangzhou Thermal Power project, which constructs a
            coal-fired thermal power plant, erects transmission lines,
            and reinforces the existing power transmission network.
            Environmental risks involving the power plant are: TPS, SO2
            and fluorides in the discharged flue gas; poisonous and
            harmful substances in the industrial effluents and living
            sewage discharges; noise pollution; the impact of ash and
            slag storage on land utilization and the atmosphere as well
            as the permeation of ash water into underground water; and
            electromagnetic radiation produced by the power lines. When
            constructing and operating the transmission line from
            Yangcheng to Jiangsu, more negative impacts are expected.
            These measures mitigate them: To reduce noise, adopt
            soundproofing measures, avoid working at night, and use a
            protective enclosure (afforesting switchyards). This
            protective barrier and the sprinkling of water will reduce
            dust. Collect water used in the switchyard and substation,
            and let it settle before discharging and reusing it. Treat
            sewage before discharging it. Replant trees to replenish
            forests. Replace the vegetal cover. Return land to farm use
            and pay compensation for agricultural land loss. Set up
            protected sites when cultural relics are found. Educate
            workers and nearby residents about power line safety. Pay
            compensation for occupying land and resettle people with
            improved public facilities and/or retrain them.

repnme.cdata!:
Guarantees improve terms of China's
            private borrowing : The Yangzhou and Zhejiang Thermal Power Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The Yangzhou and Zhejiang Thermal Power
            Projects involve construction of large, coal-fired thermal
            power plants and expansion of related transmission networks,
            and represent a major expansion in the generating capacity
            of their respective provinces (about 15 percent in Jiangsu
            and 27 percent in Zhejiang). Partial credit guarantees were
            used for both projects. The partial credit guarantee covers
            a portion of a financing against all risks. This contrasts
            with the partial risk guarantee, which can cover up to the
            entire amount of a financing against specific risks. The
            guarantees were structured to extend the maturity of
            commercial loans and provide China with greater flexibility
            in accessing world financial markets, e.g., interest rate
            (fixed or floating) and currency (to match procurement
            contracts). At the same time, the Government and Bank wished
            to minimize their exposure under the guarantee. This report
            discusses the borrowing terms and guarantee structure for
            each project and their respective costs and benefits.

Guarantees improve terms of China's
            private borrowing : The Yangzhou and Zhejiang Thermal Power Projects

7232844.majtheme: Financial and private sector development,Environment and natural resource management

abstracts.cdata!:
The main objectives of the Yangzhou
            Thermal Power Project are to: (a) support power subsector
            reforms at the provincial level, through development of
            Jiangsu Provincial Electric Power Company (JPEPC) as an
            autonomous company; (b) contribute to further
            rationalization of power tariffs; (c) promote the use of
            modern financial management techniques in transforming
            JPEPC's accounting system; (d) provide cost-effective
            and environmentally sustainable generation capacity to
            alleviate an acute shortage of power and improve the quality
            of the power supply; (e) assist in transferring modern
            technologies for large coal-fired power plants, and in
            strengthening institutional capabilities for environmental
            management and monitoring; and (f) extend technical
            assistance in management development and staff training
            program. The project consists of: (a) construction of a
            coal-fired thermal power plant with two 600-MW generating
            units and associated equipment; (b) erection of two 500-kV
            transmission lines (about 30 km long) and reinforcement of
            the existing power transmission network; (c) provision of
            engineering and construction management services; (d)
            extension of technical assistance for the development and
            implementation of improved accounting and financial
            management information systems; (e) carrying out of
            environmental management and resettlement programs; and (f)
            undertaking of management development and staff training.
